The ammonia refrigeration system and the associated safety features were designed in accordance with contemporary codes and standards.  The RMP responsible personnel (with guidance from contractors and consultants) also routinely review Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practices (RAGAGEP) for the ammonia refrigeration industry to ensure that the facility is properly maintained, and appropriate adjustments are made based on evolving industry standards.

One of the primary policies within the RMP & PSM programs is the Mechanical Integrity program that details the prescribed inspections / testing / and maintenance tasks that are conducted on all refrigeration system components + auxiliary systems.  The facility utilizes in-house Maintenance Mechanics for Daily Ammonia System Rounds (w/ log sheet) to monitor system parameters and to alert the refrigeration contractor if any conditions are out of range.  The ammonia contractor is also assigned the duties for monthly, semi-annual, and annual preventative maintenance inspections, tests, and service.

The CTI Foods ammonia refrigeration system has many safety design features including ammonia leak detectors, microprocessor controlled compressors with automatic safety cutouts, ASME certified pressure vessels, emergency stop controls, and an Emergency Refrigerant Control Box.  In addition, all pressure-rated vessels are equipped with mechanical pressure relief valves that automatically engage in case of a high pressure situation to ensure the integrity of the vessel and associated piping is protected.  Any ammonia that vents from a pressure relief valve is neutralized in the Water Diffusion Tank.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

CTI Foods (also known as S&S Foods) recognizes the companys responsibility in ensuring the safety of the public, its employees, the environment, equipment, and property.  This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration system at the CTI Foods facility in Azusa, California.

It is the policy of CTI Foods to ensure that controls are in place to limit the risks of potential ammonia releases.  CTI Foods maintains a safety committee whose members include the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  The policy is reviewed and updated as needed to ensure it remains an accurate reflection of the facility's policies regarding evacuation and the protocol to deal with emergency scenarios.

CTI Foods coordinates emergency response efforts with the local fire department and with the contracted refrigeration operation and maintenance firm.  In the case of an ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of CTI Foods to evacuate and to allow the fire department/HazMat Team to respond to the emergency.  The CTI Foods Chief Engineer and Maintenance Manager will be available for guidance and assistance.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The CTI Foods facility began operation of the facility in 1998.  The building was constructed in 1984 with several additions/modifications taking place since then.  The refrigeration system was designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations including the Uniform Mechanical Code (1994 updated to 1997), Uniform Bu

ilding Code, and the Uniform Fire Code, and utilizes anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant.

The refrigeration system at the facility was installed using R-22, a freon-based refrigerant.  It was designed with the intent of switching refrigerants to ammonia so that very few equipment/piping modifications were necessary.  The initial charge of anhydrous ammonia was received by the facility at the time that the Phase 3 expansion was finalized which included the addition of a process spiral freezer (IQF), several evaporators for new cold rooms, one compressor, and two vessels.  The refrigeration system was shut down, purged of R-22, and restarted using ammonia in November 2000.

The facility is a meat manufacturing plant that supplies product to fast-food establishments.  The facility is located at 1120 W. Foothill Blvd. in Azusa, California, just north of the Interstate 210 freeway, between Irwindale Avenue and Vernon Avenue.  The immediate area is primarily commercial with some light industrial and residential areas.  The refrigeration system was upgraded to meet the requirements of the current applicable federal, state, and local regulations including the Uniform Fire and Mechanical Codes, as well as the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations that govern the handling of anhydrous ammonia.

Refrigeration process equipment at the facility operates continuously.  Compressors and condensers cycle on and off to comply with system demand during operation.  The refrigeration system maintains low temperatures for cold storage and for blast freezing product.  The cold storage areas include: Finished Goods, Raw Goods, Blend/Grind, Dock, Freezer, IQF (Individual Quick Freeze), Fajita Process.  There are also multiple spiral freezers that are used to deep freeze meet products for distribution.

The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of high pressure liquid ammonia from the Thermosyphon Receiver (TSV-1) to the High Pressure Receiver (HPR-1), which is the main liquid storage ve

ssel in the system.  The HPR transfers high pressure liquid through the Intercooler (IC-1) in order to subcool it prior to routing to each of three Low Pressure Receivers (LPR-1, LPR-2, LPR-3).  Each Low Pressure Receiver operates an independent system with a specific process or storage freezer(s).  The HPR also supplies high pressure liquid to the Controlled Pressure Receiver (CPR-1), which maintains a constant pressure through the use of pressure regulating valves.  CPR-1 is the main liquid supply vessel for the evaporators.  As the liquid ammonia enters the various evaporator/freezer coils, it expands, reducing the temperature.

As heat from the room (or product in the Spiral Freezers) is transferred to the low temperature liquid ammonia in the coils, the ammonia is (partially) vaporized.  The suction from the evaporators is pulled to the Suction Accumulator vessel (AC-1).  The suction from each of the spiral freezers is returned to the corresponding Low Pressure Receiver.  Four compressors (HC-1, HC-2, LC-1, and BC-1) pull the gaseous ammonia from the suction vessels and work in combination to compress the low pressure ammonia to high pressure gas (hot gas).  The hot gas is discharged through a common header to the Condensers (EC-1, EC-2, EC-3), where fans and sprayed water are used to condense the ammonia in the coils back into a liquid.  As the heat from the ammonia vapor is rejected to the atmosphere, the ammonia changes phase into liquid and drains by gravity into TSV-1.

Hot gas (high stage compressor discharge) is also used for defrost in the evaporators and for pressurizing liquid transfer vessels associated with the recirculator vessels.  The system also has a Water Diffusion Tank (into which a common relief header vents), which is kept full of water in order to neutralize any ammonia vapor that is vented.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

To deal with the risks involved with ammonia refrigeration, policies a

nd programs have been developed for the CTI Foods facility to limit the risks of an accidental ammonia release and/or minimize the consequences of a significant ammonia release, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.

Policies developed for the PSM and RMP programs include employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, standard operating procedures, training, management of change + pre-startup safety review, mechanical integrity (inspections / testing / maintenance), hot work permit, contractor management, and incident investigation.  To help coordinate the various elements of the program, a management system has been established that defines responsible parties for the facility to ensure upkeep and implementation of each policy within the RMP and PSM programs.  Compliance Audits are also conducted every 3 years that can identify potential gaps in compliance and recommend actions to achieve full compliance.

Several departments within the facility (Refrigeration, Maintenance, and Safety) as well as outside resources (Ammonia Refrigeration Contractor, and a Risk Management Consultant) help to ensure the appropriate and ongoing implementation (with recordkeeping) of the various elements of the programs.  PSM Team Meetings include discussions regarding outstanding corrective action items, planned design changes to the ammonia system (if any), changes in personnel, reviewing evacuation drill results, etc.  Any significant issues that are identified are brought to plant leadership to ensure appropriate resources are allocated for timely resolutions.

The ultimate goal for CTI Foods PSM/RMP plan is to prevent accidental releases of ammonia, injuries / illnesses, and to avoid adverse impacts to the environment.  These programs enable our facility to operate the refrigeration system safely because they are based on the rules, procedures, and guidelines that govern our ammonia refrigeration system, as well as the broader

eration of the system.  In addition to routine patrols and inspections at the facility by the security company, the facility has Maintenance personnel on-site 24/7 who monitor for any abnormal conditions.  The CTI Foods ammonia refrigeration system was designed and constructed in accordance with the recognized industry codes and standards, which specifically detail requirements for safety features.

Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the system are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar to the refrigerant in a household refrigerator.  The refrigeration system is a closed-loop system without any regular emissions or releases.  Any leaks / unanticipated ammonia odors are noted and repaired immediately.


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

EPAs RMP regulation defines accident as the following: 

The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following: 

  --  On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
  --  Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (§68.42(a)).

An investigation into the facilitys accident history revealed that there have been no significant ammonia releases over the past five years (July 2019  July 2024) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds or the California state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release at the facility.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

An emergency planning and response policy has been developed at the CTI Foods facility and is maintained by the Safety department.  It is based on Cal-OSHAs requirements

for Emergency Action Plan (CCR Title 8, Section 3220), as well as EPAs Emergency Response Plan.

Facility personnel receive annual training regarding the emergency response procedures and the evacuation plan.  In the event that an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger, maintenance personnel, and/or their supervisor.  Maintenance personnel will determine what procedures and personnel are necessary to remedy the problem.  All employees evacuate to the evacuation assembly areas.  Notifications of response agencies as well the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) is also detailed the Emergency Response policy.  The CTI Foods facility also has an established relationship with the local Fire Department and County Hazardous Materials Response Team who may be called in to assist depending on the scope of an emergency situation.

The Emergency Plan policy contains procedures detailing how the facility will react to accidental ammonia releases and other emergencies such as fires, earthquakes, power outages, etc.  This policy has been coordinated with the local emergency service agencies including:  the City of Azusa Fire Department, and the Los Angeles County Fire Department HazMat Team.

The facilitys Emergency Action / Response Policy includes the following elements:

  --  Key Facility Personnel and Responsibilities
  --  Outside Agency Notification Contact Information
  --  Detailed Action Plans for Internal Departments
  --  First Aid Procedures
  --  Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures
  --  Evacuation Plans + Assembly Areas
  --  Description for Handling Small Ammonia Releases
  --  Details of Outside Assistance Available 
  --  Incident Command System
  --  Initial and Refresher Training

Evacuation drills are also organized and conducted annually by the Safety Department to supplement the training received by all employees at the facility.  As facility manageme

nt strives to improve safety at the facility, evaluations are documented with suggested improvements, and other observations from the drills.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

CTI Foods has worked to address safety issues as they arise in a continued effort to ensure a safe working environment.  Compliance Audits, PHA studies, Mechanical Integrity Inspections, in addition to routine PSM/RMP Meetings have generated recommendations to improve safety and compliance at the facility.  These include enhancing employee training policies, revising standard operating procedures, improving documentation and recordkeeping, and updating preventative maintenance policies, as well as ammonia equipment repairs.

CTI Foods, with support from contractors and consultants entrenched in the ammonia refrigeration industry, strives to ensure a safe working environment at the facility for all employees, guests, and visitors.  The facility also plans to improve safety as follows:

  --  Continued involvement of refrigeration and safety personnel in the ongoing development and implementation of the risk management policies.
  --  Participation of key personnel in industry recommended training classes to ensure the facility is aware of evolving industry standards and techniques used to encourage a safety culture at the facility.
  --  Conducting routine RMP / PSM meetings to ensure any issues identified by facility personnel, refrigeration contractors, or consultants are discussed and addressed.
  --  Conducting a Minimum System Safety Evaluation gap assessment associated with the industry recognized standard (IIAR Standard 9) for existing ammonia refrigeration systems.
  --  Reviewing and auditing the risk management and prevention policies to ensure they are maximizing the facilitys efforts at limiting the risks associated with handling anhydrous ammonia.
